Les bases

Ne prenez pas peur !!! Tous ces caract√®res farfelus ne sont enfaite pas si difficiles √† comprendre.

On va commencer par la base de la base:

HTML fonctionne avec des balises (ces < > < /> trucs). La balise <exemple> indique le d√©but d‚Äôun √©l√©ment de type exemple et </exemple> indique au contraire sa fin. Tout ce qui va se trouver entre ces balises est donc un √©l√©ment de type exemple.

<exemple> Je suis un texte de type exemple </exemple>

<titre>
Je suis un texte de type titre

<p> Je suis un texte de type paragraphe et je ne suis pas un titre </p>

Cet exemple bien qu‚Äôil soit faux a du vous permettre de bien comprendre ce fonctionnement en balises.

Passons maintenant √† quelque chose de plus concret:

<html>
<body>

La balise <html> dit tout simplement qu‚Äôil s‚Äôagit d‚Äôun code √©crit en HTML. Il y a bien d‚Äôautres langages de programmation et il faut donc bien pr√©ciser dans quelle langage ont √©crit √† chaque fois !

La balise <body> (en fran√ßais: corps) est utilis√©e pour signaler le corps de la page web. C‚Äôest ici que l‚Äôon va placer le titre, les paragraphes, les images etc.

La balise <h1> qui est l‚Äôabr√©viation de heading (en fran√ßais: titre) nous permet d‚Äô√©crire un titre. Pour √©crire un titre plus petit il suffit d‚Äôincr√©menter (faire monter) le chiffre √† c√¥t√© du h . Par exemple <h6> va √™tre un titre tr√®s petit et <h3 sera un titre de taille moyenne.

La brique de code d‚Äôau dessus va donner cela:

Bon pour la plupart du code √©crit dans cette page vous devriez reconna√Ætre une grande partie des balises.

Le bouton vert run sert √† actualiser la page sur la droite avec le code de gauche.

Je vais vous donner trois petites t√¢ches histoire de v√©rifier que vous avez-bien tout compris jusqu‚Äô√† maintenant:

  1. Changer le titre Hello world avec votre nom et pr√©nom

  2. Ajouter un titre de petite taille en dessous du titre avec votre nom et pr√©nom (anciennement Hello world) indiquant le nom de votre √©tablissement et votre classe

Fini ? ü•≥

Voici ma solution:

Les listes

Bon j‚Äôimagine que vous ne pouvez √™tre r√©sum√© √† juste votre nom pr√©nom et ann√©e scolaire‚Ä¶

Ajoutons vos activit√©s favorites sur votre site web ! Dans un paragraphe, √©crivez en dessous de votre ann√©e scolaire ce que vous aimez faire.

Moi c‚Äô√©tait facile:

Pour faire une liste il faut deux balises: Les balises <ul> signifiant ‚Äúunordered list‚Äù (en fran√ßais: liste d√©sordonn√©e). Cette balise marque le d√©but et la fin de la liste. Ensuite nous avons les balises <li> qui sont les acronymes de ‚Äúlist item‚Äù (en fran√ßais: √©l√©ment de liste) pour chaque √©l√©ment que l‚Äôon veut mettre dans notre liste.

  <li>Manger de la salade</li>

Beaucoup mieux pas vrai ?

On peut m√™me rajouter un titre avant la liste:

Les liens

Et si on rajoutait un lien vers votre site favori ?

Pour cela il faut s‚Äôarmer de la balise <a> . Voici un petit exemple:

A l‚Äôint√©rieur de la premi√®re balise <a> on place l‚Äôargument href qui d√©finit l‚Äôurl de notre site. Entre nos deux balises <a> et </a> on place le texte qui appara√Ætra comme √ßa .

Voici la balise qu‚Äôil nous faut:

Ici la balise image a besoin d‚Äôun argument src , acronyme de source . Nous allons y mettre le lien vers notre image.

L‚Äôimage de chats dans l‚Äôexemple ne va pas marcher car elle n‚Äôest pas accessible sur nos ordinateurs mais nous pouvons choisir une image disponible sur internet.

Une image de manchot vous va ? On va aller la chercher sur wikipedia a cette adresse: Manchot empereur ‚Äî Wikip√©dia

Copiez le lien √† la place de photo_de_chats.png et le tour est jou√© :

  • Mettre un smiley sur votre page

  • Sachant que la balise pour mettre en gras un texte est: <b> Mettre en gras votre pr√©nom

  • L‚Äôattribut style permet de colorer (et plus) votre texte: <h1 style="color: blue;"> va rendre le texte du titre de couleur bleue. Mettez un peu de couleur dans votre site !

entry.title: Guide to a wholesome Python dev environment

link.title: Guide to a wholesome Python dev environment

entry.content:
I started coding with python, at the time I was 17 and barely knew about how much is the development environment important. Not just the computer itself is important but furthermore the Software. I was using windows and the basic Python IDE for an approx. 1000 lines project.

Module import was a nightmare for me as much as learning the language.

I recently faced a problem related to modules. My system‚Äôs Python version was 3.8 and I needed the 3.6 version for the script to run. Furthermore, I needed 3.6 version cryptodome module.

Some Qwant searches, later on, I found about Pipenv and Pyenv.

Pyenv

Pyenv allows us to have multiple python versions in one OS. By changing the symlinks and the Path variable it manages to change the direction of the Python commands and redirect to the other python versions.

Here is a link to the documentation, I may have done mistakes while explaining the process. Here are the main commands of Pyenv.

But What if we want to install modules alongside our newly created Python version?

Well it‚Äôs ‚Äúcomplicated‚Äù

I had many problems and issues and that‚Äôs why I recommend the following tool :

Pipenv

Pipenv eases the problem of Python and Pip version Pyenv had. It creates a Pyenv environment with a Pip too.

Said like this, Pipenv is the dream come true of Python developers.

It isn‚Äôt.

Pipenv has sometimes problems with its pipenv.lock. I had a problem when managing the modules for my Deep Reinforcement Learning you can look at there. The Pipenv install "module" command was taking an eternity and I seemed broken.

And here‚Äôs how I found Poetry.

Poetry

From Poetry‚Äôs website: Python packaging and dependency management made easy

And trust me it is easy!

I didn‚Äôt experience bugs about *.lock or colossal wait during a command. It is simple and effective.

But Poetry doesn‚Äôt change the Python version by itself, you have to create a Pyenv environment with the chosen version and then in the environment init a Poetry project. Look at their amazing documentation if you need some help.

entry.title: Optimize your Linux experience
entry.content:
If you are interested in Gnu+Linux you‚Äôre in the right place. I started using Linux as my daily drive 2 years ago. At the time I barely knew Linux. Here you‚Äôll find my main tools that enable me to have a nice setup and be productive as hell.

The shell

Is one of the main tools if not the main tool of a Linux computer. You will spend a lot of time there and you have to be comfortable in there.

Most of the distros are shipped with Bash. It‚Äôs a great and powerful tool but for me it wasn‚Äôt very enjoyable. Many times my tab completion did not work because of a typo. Other times it wasn‚Äôt handy when selecting items displayed by the tab command. Bash‚Äôs tab auto-completion isn‚Äôt good enough.

But then I heard of Zsh, a child of Bash.

Zsh

If you had already learned Bash and started to be confident using it then don‚Äôt worry. Zsh and Bash are very similar. Most commands are identical and the logic is the same. Although they seem identical, Zsh have some improvements it‚Äôs father has not !

Tab Auto-completion

is great.

You can navigate through the tab results with your arrow keys or just pressing tab to hop to the next element.

A misspelled cd documents will transform into cd Documents magically !

Style

Zsh supports many themes. I don‚Äôt say Bash hasn‚Äôt but it‚Äôs good to know.

Oh my Zsh !

Is a great bundle of plugins and themes ! It is an incontournable of Zsh.

I won‚Äôt go through the plugins as they are already documented in their website.

Be Carefull: you have to use the .zshrc instead of the .bashrc .

Battery optimization

A lot of students and developers out there use laptops as main computers when it comes to work. Most of our devices doesn‚Äôt last a day. I see a lot of colleagues that are plugged in more than two times a day and they make me suffer because Linux has a lot of battery optimization tools.

TLP

I don‚Äôt know what TLP stands for but I know it gives me more than 2h of battery ! The install and setup is straightforward. Satisfaction guaranteed !

Here is the link to the documentation !

Powertop

It is another one battery optimizer. It gives me the same results that with TLP.

Zram, Zswap or Zcache ?

Linux offers many solutions when it comes to optimize. You have seen two battery optimization tools. But what about Ram optimization ?

When you define partitions for your Linux OS, you are often offered a Swap partition. Swap is a ‚Äúfake‚Äù Ram, it acts like it but as it is stored in your hard drive it is much slower than your Ram (physical). Yet not, don‚Äôt delete that partitions because Swap is very useful.

So here we face multiple positions :

  • If you don‚Äôt have a Swap partition then go for Zram

  • If you have Swap go for Zswap

  • If you like risks and want bleeding edge tools go for Zcache, is it not ready yet but it does a better job than Zswap.

    If you want to know more about it, I recommend you to read this post on StackExchange.

Gnome

For the Ubuntu or the elementary OS you may know your DE (desktop env.) is GNOME. I personally use Gnome under Wayland and I find it very good. It is the main alternative of Kde at this time and same you‚Äôre not fan of WM‚Äôs (Window Managers).

Gnome vanilla is nice but can be improved

If you don‚Äôt use Ubuntu then you may want to use Snapcraft as well. It is a widely popular ‚ÄúApp‚Äù Store. It is developed by Canonical so only Ubuntu based distributions support it in native. But other distros can use it too !

If you build your Linux from scratch you may want to have Flatpack too. It is installed on Gnome by default.

One thing that is very important is to be careful of the permissions of the snap/flatpack package. They are usually very restricted (i.e. can only use the ~/ by default). If you have a package that needs access to /bin or /usr you have to give then the access to it. You can learn more about it there.

¬†UnixPorn

Gnome isn‚Äôt as flexible as Wm‚Äôs or Kde when it comes to style. But it can change a lot and improve.

One of the mains reasons to choose Linux over Windows or Mac is that you can and you may tailor your OS for your personal needs. You don‚Äôt use a ‚Äúfor everyone‚Äù OS. You have your own OS that is optimized for your workflow.

For that you have to install gnome-tweak-tools. This module enables you to install extensions from GNOME Shell Extensions. It can be added with ease from this website. If you want to change the style then. You‚Äôll find extensions such as Caffeine, Dash to Dock, User Themes etc.

I recommend you use Gnome Shell Themes - Gnome-look.org as theme store for Gnome. The themes are easily installable as you have a superb helper.
